review.title: Preference at First Sight
review.abstract: We consider decision-making and game scenarios in which an agent is limited by his/her computational ability to foresee all the available moves towards the future - that is, we study scenarios with short sight. We focus on how short sight affects the logical properties of decision making in multi-agent settings. We start with single-agent sequential decision making (SSDM) processes, modeling them by a new structure of "preference-sight trees". Using this model, we first explore the relation between a new natural solution concept of Sight-Compatible Backward Induction (SCBI) and the histories produced by classical Backward Induction (BI). In particular, we find necessary and sufficient conditions for the two analyses to be equivalent. Next, we study whether larger sight always contributes to better outcomes. Then we develop a simple logical special-purpose language to formally express some key properties of our preference-sight models. Lastly, we show how short-sight SSDM scenarios call for substantial enrichments of existing fixed-point logics that have been developed for the classical BI solution concept. We also discuss changes in earlier modal logics expressing "surface reasoning" about best actions in the presence of short sight. Our analysis may point the way to logical and computational analysis of more realistic game models.

sections.heading: 2 Modeling Single-agent sequential decision-making
sections.text: Let's start by defining a structure called the preference-sight tree for modeling sequential decision-making processes by a single agent. Using this model, we then clarify the role that vision plays by discussing a series of changes it causes in preferences, decision-making processes, and outcomes.

sections.heading: 2.1 Models
sections.text: There are two types of models of decision scenarios that correspond to two perspectives: the former is an explicit model from the perspective of nature or an outsider / designer; the latter is the implicit model from the perspective of the actor involved or an insider / decision maker. The former is complete and perfect in the sense that the outsider has all the options in view along with the objective quality of those options, and thus can explicitly indicate the reward of each situation for the decision maker. In contrast, the decision maker's views may be limited to a near future, especially in large-scale environments. Furthermore, due to limited foresight, the actor may also falsely think about the quality of different decisions, leading to what we call subjective preferences. Both of the above perspectives are crucial: the former provides a complete picture of the environment, the latter shows the actual play of the decision maker. In this section, we first introduce an explicit model of preference trees by subjectively formulating the process of the tree, both of which we give the view of the tree.

sections.heading: 3 A Logical Analysis
sections.text: After modelling short-sightedness decision-making using preference tree models, it is instructive to see what a logical language for thinking about these models looks like, especially the role of vision in an SSDM process. So far, no such logic has been proposed, although the logic of game theory structures has been extensively studied - see [22, 20] - while there are some preliminary logical analyses of seeing itself [10, 27]. In this section, we will design a minimal and natural logical system that supports thinking about seeing in the context of individual decision-making processes, characterizes basic properties of preference trees and formally captures the results in the previous section.

sections.heading: 5 Toward Multi-player games
sections.text: While our models and outcomes are all about one-stop sequential decision-making, we believe they are applicable far beyond that. Of course, they can be extended to comprehensive multi-player game scenarios with short-sightedness, and for such a game model we can build on [14], which allows us to assume that the current player only knows his own eye, and that he believes that other players can see as much as he can see, and will play according to that belief. That is, this model excludes more complex forms of interactive knowledge and thinking, but based on the same assumption, our model in this essay can be extended directly to multiplayer cases. The only thing we need to do is to add an agent designation to SSDM: although players may change over time, everything, including vision, preference, and action, can be modelled from the perspective of the current player. We will not cite results for the extended multiplayer model, as they are quite similar to what we have already shown.

sections.heading: 6 Discussion and Conclusion
sections.text: Many recent game theory papers focusing on limited rationality have used a model of games with consciousness [15, 17, 21, 13, 16]. This approach generalizes the classical representation of large-scale games by modeling players who may not be aware of all paths. [14] While short-sightedness games are a well-educated subclass of conscious games, there is a fundamental difference in focus. Players in the latter approach may not know some industries, but they can always see some endgame strategies, while in the former the player's view only includes intermediate stories and consciously excludes all endgames. Furthermore, we have shown how short-sighted games allow for the natural coexistence of two views of a game, those of initiates and those of outsiders.
